Book.desc: {=Sa9X6NnL}A scroll filled with techniques and diagrams of swordsmanship in the Kage-ryū style. Developed in 1438 by Aisu Hisatada, Kage-ryū has established itself as one of the three major origins for the evolution of sword based-martial arts.
{=LZgp1XsH}A scroll detailing the techniques of the Shintou-ryū style, a school of swordsmanship founded by Iizasa Ienao and now counted among the three main origins of the martial arts.
{=AdaDocYA}A scroll describing the Shinkage-ryū style swordsmanship style, a school established by Kamiizumi Nobutsuna as a derivative of the Kage-ryū style.
{=fSHsjzwC}This scroll summarises the swordsmanship techniques of the Ten-ryū style, a martial arts school that also includes polearms, throwing and jūjutsu.
{=43Qyl6a1}A scroll that describes the techniques of the Toda-ryū style of swordsmanship, a school founded by Itou Kagehisa after visiting Kanemaki Michimune, a master of the Nakajou-ryū style
{=Q4dwDikE}This scroll contains the teachings of Marume Nagayoshi, a disciple of the Shintou-ryū style and founder of the Marumeshinkage-ryū school of swordsmanship.
{=YDassFgV}A scroll depicting the techniques of Houzouin-ryū school, a spear martial arts specialised in the use of the Jūmonji sickle spear to enable diverse offensive and defensive techniques.
{=IUww3Wm5}A book written by Ogasawara Mochinaga, master of archery for Shogun Ashikaga Yoshinori, that explains how to handle the bow and what to do when it is broken.
{=JG93otWp}This book contains the secret archery techniques of the Takeda Clan, passed down for generations and written down by Takeda Motonobu, head of a junior branch of the clan.
{=OJgoEU16}This book describes the horseriding technique of the Ōtsubo-ryū school, one of the classical schools of horsemanship that counts the Ashikaga Shoguns among its practitioners.
{=DY9tJx32}This scroll details the medicinal method of horse breeding and contains a depiction of the patron god of horse doctors as well as medicinal herbs used as horse medicine.

{=zDkXRI5J}This scroll contains the teachings of the Anzai-ryū school of horse medicine and describes the relationship between esoteric philosophy and horse diseases, including the methods and effects of treatment with acupuncture.
{=Nqt9jf0G}This book describes the secrets of horse treatment written by Kuwashima Hirotsuna and provides details on the parts of the horse's body and various methods of moxibustion treatment.
{=VNF4HoAS}A book containing the teachings of Hachijou Fusashige, founder of the Hachijou-ryū school of horsemanship.
{=uchnzXJ3}This book by Ogasawara Mochinaga, master of archery for Shogun Ashikaga Yoshinori, describes the manners and techniques of the Yabusame mounted archery.
{=u2cqrvgL}This book by Ogasawara Motonaga, son of Mochinaga master of archery for the Ashikaga Shogunate, details the manners and techniques of the Kasagake mounted archery.
{=FtTUGDMu}This book by Ogasawara Mochinaga, master of archery for Shogun Ashikaga Yoshinori, describes the manners and techniques of the Inuoumono mounted archery.
{=OyqAdyhX}This scroll contains a secret gunpowder recipe, originally sent by Ōtomo Sourin, and describes the method of preparation, precautions and proportions of ingredients.
{=fILAeW5I}This scroll describes the production of gunpowder techniques of the Tsuda-ryū school of artillery.
{=zPKXoJ7N}This scroll explains how to produce gun ammunition and more than 30 different types of balls, including balls made by connecting several balls with a wire and hollow balls.
{=5Id7cGyB}A book describing the art of gunnery. Written by Karaudo Chikahiro, a firearm instructor for the Jimbo clan.

{=3zsuNC4G}A set of scrolls describing the art of gunnery of the Kishiwada-ryū school of gunnery, written by Yoshida Morisada. The book details proper firing techniques and gunpowder recipes. The scroll also includes many descriptions from a spiritual perspective, linking guns with esoteric Buddhism and the role of guns in expelling evil demons.

{=2wY88rzX}A scroll containing over three decades of esoteric iconography and scriptures, assembled by Kintaibō Kakuzen. Contains over one hundred volumes and is one of the largest collections of its kind.

{=RuQ4TZhh}A scroll containing the different scholastic and oral traditions from various schools of esoteric Buddhism, organized into two hundred twenty-eight volumes. Organized by Gokurakubou Jouchou, taking over thirty years to compile.

{=OBbYaTVr}A scroll containing the oral traditions, events, and manners from various schools of esoteric Buddhism. Organized by Sōkushoin Koushū, a learned monk of the Tendai sect, who ascended Mount Hiei to study the unique sects of Buddhism.
{=unC8XMbS}A book of scrolls compiling rituals and doctrines related to mountain ascetic practices of Shugendo. Written by Akyubou Sokuden, a mountain ascetic from Mount Nikko.
{=pYmNTiMK}A book of letters testifying to the transmission of ritual doctrine in Shugendo. Written by Akyubou Sokuden, a mountain ascetic from Mount Nikko.

{=AYhzKPj2}Five volumes authored by, Utsunomiya Mikawa-nyūdou, an officer in charge of managing the Katana of the Shogun Ashikaga Yoshimitsu. He categorized katana by period and presented a genealogy of katana smiths, as well as famous swords and their measurements.
{=EwYMTiHV}A scroll containing a list of names of katana smiths by region. Includes each smith’s inscriptions, weapon characteristics, anecdotes, and genealogical information.

{=b5wKRFvG}A book finished by Saitou Toshimasa, started by his father, that covers around eight hundred forty Katana. Includes Katana from Awataguchi, Soushū, Chūgoku-Shikoku, Hokuriku, Bizen-Bitchū, and Kyushu.
{=kCaKCo01}A book classifying katana smiths in different countries into five levels of evaluation and includes highlights of their blades, the date of their production, and examples of famous swords.
{=sLDnkOCe}A book describing beliefs, origins, and history of the mountains of the Kinki region.

{=z0uNk7ZU}A book composed of experiences traveling from to Kamakura to Kyoto in 1223. It is filled with phrases from old Chinese texts, poetry, Buddhist writings, as well as detailed descriptions of landscapes and landmarks.
{=Docmd9xI}A travelogue book composed of experiences on the way from Higashiyama, Kyoto to Kamakura in 1242. It is filled with detailed descriptions of landscapes.

{=415dA2QQ}A collection of diary entries written by Abutsuni, consort of Fujiwara no Tameie. The entries focused on her travels from Kyoto to Kamakura to appeal to the Kamakura Shogunate over a territorial dispute between her son and his half-brother.

{=PGtz6eGJ}A book, written by Shōgoin Dōkō, cataloging various materials of his travels on the Hokuriku Route. Includes various writings on the Ōshū region, multiple kinds of poems, legends, and writings on historical sites.
{=UPBYYWDk}A book describing the life and culture of the warriors and provinces of Japan during the Muromachi period.
{=0juzWg0C}A collection of studies on Japan’s geography, customs, manners, and natural history. Written by Tei Shunkō who was sent to Japan to help in the suppression of Japanese Pirates.

{=efFEbXCp}A book detailing the relations between Korea and Japan, prepared by the Yi Dynasty diplomat Shin Suk-ju. It records the politics of Japan and Ryukyu, including history of diplomatic exchanges and reception of envoys.
{=ZTWHS0RH}A Japanese book on the military strategy established at the end of the Heian period. It was created as a supplementary military book to the writings of Sun Tzu.

{=shokuhob8DDdAe6}This book, is revered as one of China's major military strategy books, also known as The Art of War, written by Sonshi (Sun Tzu). With advances in organized conflict, this text has become increasingly important for strategists across Japan. Utilized as a source for the writings of Takeda Shingen.

{=SPfjkxAC}This book is revered as one of China's major military strategy books, written by Goshi (Wu Qi). With advances in organized conflict, this text has become increasingly important for strategists across Japan.
{=JQq34w3V}Revered as one of China's major military strategy books. With advances in organized conflict, this text has become increasingly important for strategists across Japan.
{=JQq34w3V}Revered as one of China's major military strategy books. With advances in organized conflict, this text has become increasingly important for strategists across Japan.
{=JQq34w3V}Revered as one of China's major military strategy books. With advances in organized conflict, this text has become increasingly important for strategists across Japan.
{=JQq34w3V}Revered as one of China's major military strategy books. With advances in organized conflict, this text has become increasingly important for strategists across Japan.
{=JQq34w3V}Revered as one of China's major military strategy books. With advances in organized conflict, this text has become increasingly important for strategists across Japan.

{=6R5Bg134}A book on the theories of writing renga, written by the court noble Nijō Yoshimoto. It describes the history and rules of renga, the spirit of renga creation, attire, and how to organize renga meetings.

{=vMQT3wfW}A book on the theories of writing Muromachi period renga, written by the renga master Sōgi. It describes the history of renga and the techniques of renga creation in a question-and-answer style, with examples.
{=19KEPyJH}This book is a collection of two thousand fifty-two renga poems, many written by samurai. Compiled by Ichijou Fuyuyoshi, Sanjōnishi Sanetaka, Sōgi and others.

{=zTf4tDVo}Written by the monk Gen’e, this book is an assortment of diverse knowledge and education necessary for social life. The contents cover food, clothing, housing, occupations, territorial management, architecture, judiciary practices, professions, Buddhism, armor, culture, and recuperation.

{=hKNscAQA}Written by the nobleman Ichijou Kaneyoshi, this book is an assortment of miscellaneous information. Includes details on the social life of samurai and court nobles, horses, armor, blacksmithing, temples, famous painters, alcoholic beverages, landmarks, memorial services, teas, and much more.

{=HwMZdP7F}Written by the nobleman Ichijou Kaneyoshi, this book is a compilation of Shintou and Buddhist Rituals, worship, processions, events, clothing, secret banquets, bad luck rites, imperial edicts, and other miscellaneous writings.

{=zyv9c1x4}A collection of explanations into the manners and systems of the Muromachi Shogunate’s warrior class, including accounts of negotiations between court nobles and samurai. Authored by Ise Sadamachi, governor of Yamashiro Province.
{=LJHypGfx}A story describing the contrasts between the Taira and Minamoto, their subsequent battles and downfalls, and the human drama of the Heian Nobles.
{=3N5nee3C}An eight volume narrative on Minamoto no Yoshitsune and his followers.
{=cwqXvgWV}A book detailing the accession of Emperor Go-Daigo. Includes the fall of the Kamakura Shogunate, and the new government and its collapse.
{=eT7w6xyJ}A Kamakura period biographical story based on the revenge of the Soga brothers in Fujino. Written in the style of a military history treatise.
{=XflIVwxR}A collection of four books on Confucious thought and five books on assorted poems, documents, rites, and other texts. It was possibly compiled in some way by Confucious himself.
{=SjVaQf1a}An Encyclopaedia by Minamoto no Shitagō, containing about three thousand entries on his opinions of various matters.

{=edDbDSHL}A book of six hundred twenty articles filled with miscellaneous meanings of Japanese and Chinese words and phrases. Includes celestial phenomena, deities, countries, inner regions, geography, plants, grass, birds, beasts and insects, human affairs, the human body, Buddhism, treasures, clothing, musical instruments, miscellaneous items, food and drink, and more.

{=AspEeudR}An Encyclopaedia of the Middle Ages, authored by Tōin Kinkata. Includes astronomy, geography, the divisions of court, literature, manners and customs, arts and crafts, religion, and taboos.
{=xFWvS5gM}An Encyclopaedia by Tōroku Hanō with eighteen sections on society, seasonal events, quantities, language, human ethics, and more.
{=r13LNEG0}A scroll filled with an assortment of writings. Includes astronomy, geography, literature, divisions of court, customs, goods, arts and crafts, religion, and taboos.

{=qYy1U6EE}A collection of thirty-one articles codifying the customary laws of maritime traders in the Seto Inland Sea. Includes regulations for ships, shipowners, sailors, maritime salvage, and nautical rituals.

{=sBKwO1Rh}Fifty-one articles comprising the codes of the Kamakura shogunate. Filled with diverse content including the duties of guardians and landowners and codifies unique samurai jurisprudence that differs from the traditional court law and manor law.

{=er6VQ05c}A commentary on the shogunate's basic code of law, the Goseibaishikimoku, authored by Kiyohara no Nobukata. The contents contain quotes and explanations of the various theories of kōke law and discusses the blending of different kōke laws within samurai families.

{=tRpBlqV8}Seventeen articles consisting of laws authored by Asakura Takakage, given to his heir Ujikage. The contents cover directives on the control of vassals, recruitment of personnel, strengthening of military power, emphasis on civil administration, fostering of territorial culture, strictness of justice, and vigilance against other domains.

{=gsOIC4l7}An assorted set of laws written by Date Tanemune detailing a number of regulations on the governance of his territory. It is characterized by detailed provisions on criminal offenses such as murder and robbery, the broad recognition of landowners' right to rule, and preferential treatment in the sale and purchase of land to craftsmen of arms and farming implements.

{=XKXBAN3A}An article of law written by Imagawa Yoshimoto detailing a number of regulations on the governance of his territory. It provides stipulation on relations between lords and peasants, boundary disputes, responses in case of conflicts and banditry, restrictions on the sale and purchase of territory, provisions for the vassal system, non-interventionist rights, and inheritance and court procedures, and much more.

{=3ybFlk33}A set of laws written by Takeda Harunobu (Shingen) for the realms under the control of the Takeda Clan. A total of fifty-five articles, It stipulates the prohibition of private wars, the regulation of letters to other domains, the prohibition of sectarian disputes, and the prohibition of private alliances.

{=l5m8ME5Y}A set of laws written by Sagara Haruhiro for the realms under the control of the Sagara Clan. Includes stipulations on the sale and purchase of rice fields, master-servant relations, water access, fines for sheltering fugitives, and prohibits the Ikko sect. Prayers by anyone other than Buddhists, Shinto, or mountain dwelling priests are strictly prohibited.
{=peUDJ52f}A medical treatise compiled by Izumo no Hirosada from the Heian period, sporting a collection of medicinal herbs across the region.

{=16fh1qth}A medical treatise compiled by Tanba Yasuyori, a doctor of acupuncture who served as court physician during the Heian period. It compiled into thirty volumes and consists of doctors' ethics, general medical theory, therapies for various diseases, health and hygiene regimen, medical techniques and medical thought.

{=vq0zLdDx}A leading medical treatise of the Kamakura period, compiled by the physician Kajiwara Shouzen. Kajiwara utilized his knowledge of medicine and references from the latest Chinese Medical texts of the period to assemble this set of volumes. Includes details on vast amount of illnesses and diagrams of internal organs.
{=irBHhwiz}Kajiwara Shouzen’s medical treatise written around 1313 and entirely in Chinese. Intended to transmit and preserve the art of medicine.

{=WOuDgTfK}Ten volumes of Yū Souritsu’s Ming dynasty medical texts reprinted and published by Asaino Sōzui, a merchant in Sakai. Intended for en-masse sale, this collection is vital for spreading knowledge on a plethora of ailments.

{=PtJNY3zY}A set of eight volumes on diseases and treatments by Manaze Dōzan. Contains information on diverse etiologies from ancient and modern Chinese sources and is vital for the cataloging and treating of numerous ailments across Japan.

{=hWxWyNii}A comprehensive collection of articles on the methods and procedures of castle building. Inside are detailed descriptions of the material, manpower, and techniques required of castles depending on their terrain and complexity.

{=jXNpbKGC}Sou Kouryo's completed collection of Shu military writings from the Song Dynasty. Each volume is filled with theories and doctrines on assorted military knowledge as well as descriptions of various siege engines and defensive equipment.
